item.title: Introducing: The Indie Indie Conversation
item.description: Hello there! I figured now was a good time to talk about a project I‚Äôve been involved with for the past couple months now. Something we like to call, the Indie Indie Conversation. The conversation is a YouTube channel shared amongst a group of indie game developers where we talk about what we do, the challenges, and the lifestyle of creating games independently for a living. I‚Äôve personally failed many attempts at starting a regular video log here on my blog, and in retrospect that may have been the uncomfortable feeling of ‚Äútalking to a wall‚Äù.

item.description: I did miss my June 23rd target date, but with good reason: I started on computer upgrades and setting up my new Laptop early. üòÄ But yes, as you approach the end of something, there are always things you forget about that still need to be done. Like this, a Computer and TV-System appropriate trailer for Smiles HD (i.e. without entire screen rotating): As you can see, that is now done.

item.title: Ending Smiles
item.description: Yes, you read that right. It is ending. For real. June 23rd is the 3 year anniversary of Smiles (as in, starting the game). I have finished every single port of the game that I had planned on doing (except console ports, both I decided to abort); Some are still in submission or need of final packaging. Days away now. item.title: Mike and Middleware
item.description: I‚Äôve been making games for a really long time now, but one thing I‚Äôve found myself rather resilient to was letting myself use Middleware. By Middleware, I mean 3rd party libraries. It‚Äôs funny since I always highly recommend that people use it (to save RIDICULOUS amounts of time), but I myself am just a really slow adopter of it. SDL is one of few long-time 3rd party libraries I use. It lets me write my game code against the PC, Mac, Linux, and a few mobiles including Palm/HP‚Äôs webOS and Nokia‚Äôs Maemo.

item.description: Happy April 1st! To start, my thing to make you laugh. I‚Äôll be finishing this up in the coming weeks. item.description: Added a toggle button for Windowed and Fullscreen today, and made it actually work. item.title: Smiles in 64 bits
item.description: So I spent the evening getting Smiles working in 64bit Linux (Ubuntu 10.10) as well as the Mac. Here are the results: And the Mac again: And a closeup of the processes section: Getting it working on the Mac wasn‚Äôt really necessary, but I really like Xcode‚Äôs debugging tools. They made tracing the issue very straightforward. I had two VNC windows going almost constantly, as I‚Äôd make changes on the Workstation PC, commit to SVN, and sync on both the Mac and the Zotac.

item.title: Ubuntu on the Zotac
item.description:
Before I get to the meat of this post, last night I finished my ‚Äúearly‚Äù Mac App Store TODO list. I *COULD* submit it now, but there‚Äôs a bug with submissions. My iPad version is called Smiles HD, and so will be the Mac App Store version. Right now the names conflict, so I have to wait until this is fixed.

For now it‚Äôs ‚Äúdone‚Äù. I sent the binary to some friends to double-check compatibility. So while I wait, it‚Äôs time to get on other ports.

Notably, my Mac binary is only a 32bit Intel binary. My source does compile in 64bit mode, but runs in to issues. Smiles isn‚Äôt a game that needs 64bit addressing, but unlike Windows and OSX, 64bit Linux doesn‚Äôt support 32bit applications (not stock at least). So one of my next portability challenges is making my Smiles codebase support 64bit Intel and AMD chips.

* * *

Aside from my Workstation PC and Macs, I have a lot of Netbooks. The Netbooks are what I usually use for Linux development. Unfortunately, all the Netbooks I currently have don‚Äôt support 64bit instructions (the current generation Intel Atom CPU‚Äôs do).

So I ordered one of these, a Zotac MAG Nettop PC. For about $250 CAD (with a rebate), it‚Äôs a dual core Atom 330 running at 1.6 GHz, 2 GB of RAM, 160 GB Hard Drive, with an NVidia ION chipset (GeForce 9400M). I‚Äôm technically lacking an AMD and ATI test machine, but I do have one of each elsewhere I can turn to if I run in to problems (both running Windows).

The version I ordered isn‚Äôt the most up to date (original NVidia ION, last year‚Äôs Dual Core Atom), which is on purpose. This is both a development and a test machine, and if I can buy one for $250, so will other people looking for a low cost PC‚Ä¶ not that an NVidia 9400M is anything to shake a stick at either. This gives me a good cross section of graphics hardware I can test in Linux (Intel GMA on the Netbooks, NVidia on the Nettop).

When I purchased my first Netbook a couple years back (an Acer Aspire One), I started a secondary blog where I recorded all my setup notes, thoughts, and learnings (new word!!).

http://aspireonedev.blogspot.com/

So here‚Äôs an extra little blog I created to share the super technical and super nuance details of a little project of mine. Turning a stock 8GB SSD Acer Aspire One running Linpus Linux in to an ideal lightweight coding machine.

More than anything, it was a blog about me learning to use Linux for development. I know a lot more about working inside Linux now, but posts of mine like this I found extremely helpful when I started doing things like Moblin:

http://aspireonedev.blogspot.com/2008/10/intalling-console-applications.html

So the remainder of this blog post will be me walking through the setup steps taken to set up this new machine for development, and get my 32bit makefile running and building code. In retrospect, the recorded setup details should be identical no matter the CPU architecture (32bit or 64bit, though this was me doing it 64bit style).

item.title: As expected, twas the Cache
item.description: Not much to say or show, just that the performance problem was due to the textures being larger than the texture cache. As it is now, on my Mac mini the game runs at under 8% CPU usage in the menus and Zen, and under 10% in Drop. The largest texture is 1024√ó1024, DXT5 compressed (4:1, or 1 MB). Before it was 1024√ó1024 uncompressed 32bit RGBA (1:1, or 4 MB). That either means the GMA 950 in these older Mac‚Äôs has 1 MB of cache, or perhaps 2 MB (I didn‚Äôt check with 16bit RGBA textures, but it‚Äôs unlikely).

item.title: Macs and Cheese
item.description: This week I‚Äôve been downloading updates for all my tools. Linux distros, as well as Apple tools and OS updates. Yesterday was spent trying to get a 64bit version of Ubuntu running on my Media Center PC (i.e. my old dual core AMD workstation PC, now hooked up to the projector). My initial attempt of installing it to a USB key didn‚Äôt work, but I did eventually get it working using WUBI.

item.title: Minimize and Exit buttons in a screen layout
item.description: Going through my Smiles HD TODO/Wishlist, one thing I‚Äôve been meaning to add to the game for a long time was a minimize button. The game runs on several multitasking OS‚Äôs, but your only option up until now was to exit. Now, if the OS supports it, it can be suspended in to the background with just a click.

item.title: Smiles for PC’s, Mac’s and Linux’s Month (and Droids?)
item.description: Well alright. I agreed to do a little contract gig back during the summer that finally caught up with me, so the past couple weeks were spent on that. Yesterday we finally finished and submitted that, so I‚Äôm free to work on what‚Äôs really important: Smiles HD for computers! Wait‚Ä¶ what!? Okay, well I still do have my new-game scheduling plans detailed in the last post, but I‚Äôll be slightly delaying that start time yet again, but not by much.

item.title: Future Schedule Thoughts
item.description: It‚Äôs now half way through the month, and progress on my ‚ÄúOctober Game‚Äù is minimal to say the least. I suppose that was to be expected, since I did have several things to finish this month. My week-days have been filled with various tasks, leaving only weekends to work on this new thing. Next week I‚Äôll be busy with my ‚Äú1 more thing‚Äù, leaving me the last week of October for a final crunch.

item.description: Since the summer I‚Äôve been chatting with Microsoft about bringing Smiles to Windows Phone 7. item.title: A (rough) AppUp porting guide
item.description:
One of the items on my seemingly infinite TODO list is to write an article about how to port an iPhone game to AppUp. Another item is to rework my blog layout and list all the actually useful content written here. I‚Äôve yet to do either, but I think I have here a good compromise for the 1st.

I do a-lot of emailing, and this past week I had a chat with a fellow developer who wanted some advice on porting his game. I sometimes forget about the hours of work that went in to figuring out the the right combination of Unix tools, Windows tools, cross platform libraries, and how to smash them together until they make something that actually works. So I sent him a very to the point list of things that I do.

Sometime after that, I realized I should just post that e-mail.

item.title: The final mobile port (for now)
item.description: I actually finished on Sunday, but the final mobile port of Smiles is now sent. The port is for Samsung‚Äôs Bada mobile platform. I was pleasantly surprised how straight forward it was to get things up and running there. The system API is very much like a C++ version of Apple‚Äôs ObjC iPhoneOS API. The whole endeavor took no more than 4 days worth of work. So done! I will continue to support the existing plethora of ports as needed, but now it‚Äôs time to switch gears, and get going on the new project!

item.title: Netbook Smiles updates sent
item.description: So finally, Smiles 1.1 for Netbooks (The Intel AppUp Center) has been submitted. Also, though Moblin Netbook Smiles was submitted last week, it came back with a very minor issue. That is now fixed, and sent as well. So Netbook Smiles == all done. I have 1 last mobile port I‚Äôm doing, Samsung Bada. Again, Google wont let Canadians make Google Checkout Merchant accounts, so Android and NACL Smiles ports will be pending that, and a good motivator for each.

item.title: Smiles on Nokia N900 (Maemo)
item.description: The latest in the seemingly endless stream of ports (the first of the two implied quicker ports I‚Äôm doing‚Ä¶ though the 2nd one is sounding not so quick after all). The N900 is a Linux (Maemo) based device, so I was literally able to pick up where I finished the Moblin (Linux) ports. Admittedly, it was a bit of a scary port, since I was only initially able to get the game to do about 10 fps.

item.title: Greatest Port Ever (heh)
item.description: Realistic? Heck no! But totally awesome!

item.title: VNC Poster Boy
item.description: Heh, I certainly wasn‚Äôt expecting this. RealVNC has a rotating twitter quotes on their front page, and it seems I‚Äôm now part of the rotation. And yes, that is a real quote; I do think VNC is awesome. Admittedly, I‚Äôve been using UltraVNC on my PC‚Äôs recently, though I do run their iPhone client. üòâ Thanks for the tip Adam. ‚Äì ‚Äì ‚Äì I FINALLY submitted my Moblin (Linux) AppUp port of Smiles late last night.

item.title: Rapid Fire Porting
item.description: I have a goal of switching my focus entirely to a new project starting in July, which is about 6 weeks away. My 30th birthday is the 6th, so my folks have been joking that‚Äôll be my gift to myself. Happy Birthday Mike, you can do something else now‚Ä¶ heh. So to make that happen, I need to power through my list of pending platforms I want to cover, before back-burner‚Äôing the rest.

item.title: Blogging for 5 years now… wuh, really!?
item.description: I wont pretend this blog features much quality content, but it seems I‚Äôve been filling it with nonsense for 5 years now (started May 1st 2005). So wow! Completely unrelated, yet an appropriate way to celebrate, I now have an image at the top of the site. Wow ‚Äòeh? Now I am a whole 2 steps away from the default WordPress theme (the 1st step was widening the layout). The past week I‚Äôve been busy with a variety of things.

item.title: Smiles running on the Palm Pre, plus other things
item.description: One of the sessions I saw at GDC this year was Palm‚Äôs talk about their new PDK (i.e. their native SDK). The promise was a Linux based mobile device featuring SDL and OpenGL ES. Since my Windows and Linux code base also uses SDL and OpenGL, that certainly caught my attention. In theory, all I need to do is just recompile my Linux version with their tools and I‚Äôm done, right?

item.title: Automobiles, Interviews, all Smiles
item.description: To say 2010 has been a busy year would be an understatement. While we were all waiting for Apple to confirm the existence of the iPad, I was busy tweaking, improving, and porting my game Smiles to a bunch of new platforms. The most significant port by far was to Netbook PCs for Intel‚Äôs AppUp Center, a brand new App Store coming soon to Netbooks everywhere. To say Intel and AppUp have been good to me, that would be another understatement.

item.title: Smiles HD bug list (and launch day thoughts)
item.description: Wow! So that was iPad launch day. I‚Äôll talk a little more about the ‚Äúday 1 FREE‚Äù experiment after some results. Just before disappearing, the game was sitting at #60 in the Top FREE Apps (#13 Top FREE Games). Earlier today, I caught it at #55. Anyways, I said I wasn‚Äôt going to talk about this! Like many other developers, I shipped the game to Apple for launch day without actually testing it on a real device.

item.title: Smiles HD is GOLD!
item.description: A long day of waiting, but now that I have you my little green dot, it can finally end. Ahhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh!

item.title: Smiles HD – Gameplay Videos!
item.description: Oh hey. Like literally an hour or two after that big epic blog post of mine, Apple let us know we could submit early. So I crunched the game together and did exactly that. Here‚Äôs some final video footage of the game.

item.title: Smiles HD – Development Video – a typical game
item.description: Here‚Äôs an early development video of Smiles HD. The video shows a typical game of Drop at the Normal difficulty (typical for me at least).

item.title: Ramping up for iPad: Smiles HD
item.description: Alright! The iPad is coming soon, as is a brand new version of Smiles. As we speak I‚Äôm putting the finishing touches on Smiles HD, the all new higher resolution and slightly redesigned iPhone game coming soon to the iPad. Now, in the eyes of Apple I‚Äôm nobody special. So like many of you, I‚Äôll be heading down to my local Apple store on launch day to pick me up an iPad‚Ä¶ with one slight difference.

item.title: Mike the Multi-Winner and GDC Champion
item.description: So, holy cow! GDC was absolutely insane! I almost don‚Äôt know where to start, but lets start from the beginning. First thing first, I won again!! Yes, as if winning a free car wasn‚Äôt enough, I also won a free trip to GDC. So Intel ended up covering my flight, putting me up in a fancy hotel, gave me some spending money, treating me to dinner, AND giving me nearly front row seats to a San Jose Sharks hockey game!

item.title: Personalizing your GDC pass
item.description: Ordinarily, greeting someone by glancing at their chest might be seen as a little rude (especially a lady), but at GDC it‚Äôs encouraged! Yes I‚Äôm talking about the passes, not making a pass. The passes do a good job of helping you connect a face to a name, and even a company, but you don‚Äôt always know who made or represents what. GDC passes include a relatively large pocket, so you could either make something to insert behind your name card, or cover the pass with some strategically placed stickers.

item.title: A Very Different GDC (for me)
item.description: So last year, I was an IGF Mobile finalist. This little game of mine stood alongside iPhone favorites like Edge and Fieldrunners, vying for the ‚ÄúBest Mobile Game‚Äù award. And if I had won, ‚Ä¶ well, I have no idea. Even just being a finalist has been great for me, so I‚Äôd image it would have been MORE great. üòâ That was 2009, and this is 2010. This year started out as my ‚Äúlow key‚Äù and ‚Äúquiet‚Äù GDC.

item.title: The “Intel is awesome” post
item.description: So hey. Back in December I finished up a 1.0 port of Smiles for Netbooks, and sent it to Intel by their early contest deadline. And hey, guess what? Link here. Second place! That‚Äôs awesome. üòÄ So hey, what does 2nd place actually mean? Wow. So I guess I‚Äôve got a pretty good story now when mingling at GDC. üòÄ I‚Äôll post some photos once it arrives. Woohoo!

item.title: Smiles HD for iPad
item.description: I‚Äôm sure this will surprise no one, but yes I‚Äôll be releasing Smiles HD for iPad. The iPad port will be based on my current Smiles code running on Netbooks and some Windows Mobile devices (Samsung Omnia II), but I‚Äôm in the process of adding several more enhancements on top of that. I‚Äôll dive in to more of the specifics as iPad launch gets closer. The biggest different between iPhone Smiles and my current code is I‚Äôve squared the playfield (was 9√ó8, now 8√ó8) and added rotation buttons.

item.title: Smiles for Windows Available… sort of!
item.description: As part of Intel‚Äôs new AppUp Center launched at CES yesterday, Smiles is now available for select Windows PC‚Äôs of the XP and 7 varieties. http://www.intel.com/consumer/products/appup.htm The store is very new and beta. It‚Äôs designed specifically for Netbooks and the OEMs that make them, but is freely available to for everyone to test and purchase from. item.title: Mike’s 2009
item.description: So wow. That‚Äôs finally it for 2009. Like doing taxes ever year, I feel a special sort of obligation that I write some sort of retrospective, especially after such an eventful year as this one. Far more awesome than taxes. üòâ I wasn‚Äôt sure where to start, so I ended up categorizing aspects of the year. I‚Äôll free form rant about each topic as I come to it. Let‚Äôs begin.

item.description: As the title suggests, I came 4th place with Smiles Zen (in Italian). I imagine the English versions will be available soon. Samsung‚Äôs approval department might be taking xmas off though. üòâ Happy Holidays folks!

item.title: Another Port

The other thing off my mind is Intel‚Äôs contest. Netbook ports were due today, the same day as the results for Samsung.

item.title: A Port and a Compo
item.description: Wow. To say the last 3 weeks have been busy would be an understatement. First of all, I ported Smiles to a new phone. The Samsung Omnia II, a Windows Mobile phone with a beautiful amoled screen and a custom GPU. Some photos. For those keeping score, the game unfortunately runs a little slow on the Omnia II. It‚Äôs definitely playable, but the GPU is no PowerVR SGX. I did what I could in the time I had, optimized my shaders and all that, but it‚Äôs what it is.

item.title: Stocked and Loaded
item.description: An intense month of work awaits. Crunch time, and then some! Early/Mid last week, I spec‚Äôd out the plan for my time between now and GDC. Quite a busy schedule, with a lot of really cool things coming up. Smiles stuff, and a quick collaboration with a friend, which I‚Äôll talk more about later. I should have plenty to talk about with my internet colleagues in March. But the icing on the cake was a development Wednesday/Thursday of last week.

item.title: (Annoying) Differences between Visual Studio and GCC
item.description:
Or in other words, awesome C an C++ language features you‚Äôll learn to love in GCC, that‚Äôll break your heart if you ever have to use Visual Studio. üòâ

This is a list I collected whilst getting my Smiles PC code to compile with Visual Studio 2008. Most have no equivalent in Visual Studio, but one simply has a slightly different syntax (compatible too).

item.title: Aspects of Smiles
item.description: The first step with Smiles was to up the art resolution. That way, I could cleanly resize to any resolution below 4x the iPhone (1920√ó1280). Double iPhone will work windowed on most desktop LCD and 720p screens (960√ó640), and quadruple in a window fits on a 30‚Ä≥ Dell or Apple Cinema display, but we could do better.
